results.title: China Rising
results.creator_credit: Gwyneth Hughes, Granite Productions and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: A series of three two part programs that detail the history of China during a number of tumultuous stages in its history. The first program explores the period in Chinese history between the 1920s through to the 1940s, seen through the eyes of the people living in Shanghai, as the country moved from the colonial rule of the English and Japanese and the disjointed rule of the warlords to a unification movement led by the Nationalists under Chiang Kai-Shek and subsequent attempts by the Japanese to regain control. The second two part program covers the history of Communist China from the mid 1930s to the 1960s, where the chinese Communists retreated following defeat by the Nationalists in the walk later known as the Long March, only to regroup and counter attack in the form of the Peoples Liberation Army to drive the Nationalists out of power and to exile in Taiwan. Part three of the series covers the period of Mao’s Cultural Revolution and the subsequent changes which inspired the student democracy movement of the late 1980’s through discussion of the revolution’s impact on families and the classes and the economic reforms of the 1980s following the revolutions decline. This comphrehensive documentary uses rare archival footage and interviews with the chinese people of the time and engages with the impact this constantly revolutionary period of Chinese history had on their lives. Each program in the series includes Teachers notes.

results.title: China dolls
results.creator_credit: Tony Ayres, Helen Bowden and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In this documentary about the experience of being gay and Asian in Australia, filmmaker Tony Ayres blends his own story about coming to terms with his race and sexuality with that of men he interviews. Born in Hong Kong, Ayres grew up in Australia denying his Chinese identity. Ironically, it was only when he realised he was gay that the full implications of his ethnicity became apparent. Focusing on the contradictions of being part of a ‘double minority’, Ayres exposes the ways that the ideals of beauty and youth promoted in contemporary gay culture are saturated with racial stereotypes. Where the dominant iconography of sexual desirability and masculinity is almost exclusively Caucasian, gay Asian men are either rendered invisible or portrayed as soft and ‘feminine’. Ayres own story of coming to terms with the complexities of his identity and the stories of the subjects of his film (who include photographer and performance artist William Yang and actor Anthony Wong) reveal how gay Asian Australian men are overturning old stereotypes and forging new identities for themselves.

results.title: China clay. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Ronald Haines and British Foundation Pictures
results.brief_description: Part one shows the Cornish china clay pits and the process that separates it from impurities and prepares it for shipment to the pottery mills. Part two shows how the raw clay becomes plates and figurines. Also how decorations are added. Shows enormous handmade Royal Doulton vase.
results.description: Part one shows the Cornish china clay pits and the process that separates it from impurities and prepares it for shipment to the pottery mills. Part two shows how the raw clay becomes plates and figurines. Also how decorations are added. Shows enormous handmade Royal Doulton vase.

results.title: China clay
results.creator_credit: Duncan Ross, Central Office of Information and Films of Fact
results.brief_description: A study of the various uses of china clay obtained from the Cornwall region of England. Begins with footage at a quarry, showing the excavation and treatment process before it reaches a kiln for drying. China clay sand, a by-product of this process is recycled and used in the manufacture of concrete block, extensivley used in the construction of the ‘Cornish Unit House’. Presents interior and exterior footage of this type of home. Scenes within a china factory capture the skills of potters and painters who convert the clay into decorative household products. Also shows the manufacturing process in a paper mill which uses a combination of china clay and wood-pulp to produce newsprint. Commentary by Geoffrey Sumner. Editing by Len Green.

results.title: China after Tianamen
results.creator_credit: Irv Drasnin, Boston, Drasnin Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: On June 4th 1989, the world watched as the tanks rolled into Tianamen Square, dispersing the students who had carried out their non-violent protest for democratic reform in China. After Tianamen, China would never be the same. Paradoxically, along with the tightening of security, the increased presence of surveillence and miltary forces, there has been a rise in consumerism, entrepreneurship and commercialism as China takes it place in the global marketplace. This program looks at the aftermath of Tianamen, examining issues such as the state’s control of the arts, the expression of dissent, particularly reflected in the growing interest in religion, and the economic and social changes which are changing the face of China.

results.title: China's child
results.brief_description: Looks at population control measures implemented in China and economic and sociological implications of these. Couples must be over twenty-four years of age before marrying and are told when to conceive a child.

results.title: Chile: hasta cuando?(Captioned)
results.brief_description: An account of the political unrest in Chile, 12 years after the murder of Allende and the installation of military dictatorship under General Pinochet. This powerful documentary is also about the struggle of the people of Chile. Under the dictatorship of Pinochet some 50,000 Chileans were detained, many are missing believed dead.

results.title: Children, Television and Violence
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Monday Conference”.
Dr. William Belsen, who has carried out extensive research on children, television and violence, talks with a Monday Conference audience comprising researchers, industry people, teachers and parents. Many interesting areas are touched upon including the difficulty of establishing casual links between television violence and real violence carried out by children, how parents can identify which programs are likely to be “casually” violent, and the possible cathartic effect of television violence

results.title: Children waiting
results.creator_credit: Robert Giles, Jean Wadlow, Charles Barker Films and National Playing Fields Association
results.brief_description: Illustrates the need for playing facilities for children who live in cities. Shows an adventure playground at Stevenage, Kent, as an example of what can be achieved through community organization and effort. Suitable for Tertiary/Teacher education.
